results.title: Pifuskin
results.brief_description: Sometimes a man just has to scratch. This short animation explores notions of iritation of skin, of perception of self, of blood and bodily function.

results.title: Burger Burger
results.creator_credit: Gavin Jun Jie Tan and Huang Shicong
results.brief_description: The story of a marooned explorer who meets some local wildlife, with a scary - but eventually serendipitous - outcome. This colourful, fast-paced short animation won Best Animation at the Singapore Short Film Awards 2011.

results.title: Cyborg Chicken
results.brief_description:
In the hen-house, the story of the brave ‘Cyborg Chicken’ is passed down from the Old Master Rooster to the next generation. A story about difference, courage and saving the future, ending with a call to “STOP Global Warming!”.
Voice acting: Anthony Baptiste, Marcus Marshall, Kelsey Noel.
Production design: Kelsey Noel.
Character design: Dominic Ross

results.title: Big Game
results.creator_credit: Jarrod Hasenjager and The Animation School (Cape Town)
results.brief_description:
Bobo, a lonely monster, is set to spend another birthday alone, until a cunning monster hunter throws him a killer surprise party!
Animators: Sarah Scrimgeour, Aarin Lehmkuhl, Romy Latter, Miro Kolenic, Jarrod Hasenjager, Matthew Furnell.
Animation: Aarin Lehmkuhl, Matthew Furnell
Production Designers: Jarrod Hasenjager, Sarah Scrimgeour, Romy Latter
Sound: Andrew Schar, Kamil Govender

results.title: Picturesque Tasmania
results.creator_credit: G Gamon and Australia. Dept of Commerce. Cinema Branch
results.brief_description: Produced by the Cinema Branch, Australian Department of Commerce. A driving tour of Tasmania from Hobart along the western, northern, eastern and southern coasts focussing on the natural scenery. A number of towns and their various industries can also be seen such as trout hatcheries, the Mt Lyell mine, hops and apple growing. Source: NFSA Film Australia Collection.

results.title: Among the Hardwoods
results.creator_credit: Lyn Maplestone and Commonwealth of Australia
results.brief_description: An earlier silent version of this film was made in 1927 as part of the ‘Know Your Own Country’ series by renowned pioneer cinematographer Lacey Percival. In mid-1936 Bert Ive and a sound recordist revisited the Pemberton region of south-west Western Australia where they filmed and also recorded natural sounds from the forest. Whilst this re-edited film was half the length of the original, Ive’s director Lyn Maplestone created greater impact by lingering on the sights and sounds of logging trees in the Jarrah and Karri forests. The film focuses on the atmosphere of the forest as it was irrevocably changed by the axe and saw of the loggers. Scenes shot for the silent version (but not always used) can also be seen being processed and screened in ‘Telling the World’ (1929). Source: NFSA Film Australia Collection.

results.title: Telling the World
results.brief_description: As the title suggests, ‘Telling The World’ was made for an overseas audience as was much of the Government film unit’s output. It covers the roles and functions of the Cinema and Photographic Branch and shows Bert Ive filming some of the iconic images he would capture of important Australian events and places. The opening sequence shows a meeting between the Cinema Branch’s Officer-in-Charge Lyn Maplestone and Bert Ive, who appear periodically throughout the film. Ive continued to work for the branch until his death in 1939. The film has been sepia toned, a specialised chemical treatment enhancing black and white film with a warmer tone. Some scenes in the processing laboratory are tinted red. An excellent example of the period’s documentary and innovative filmmaking techniques. Source: NFSA Film Australia Collection.

results.title: The Calling
results.creator_credit: Jodie Passmore, Bridget Ikin, Felix Media and Angelica Mesiti
results.credit_line:
Angelica Mesiti

Ian Potter Moving Image Commission, ACMI Collection

Three channel video installation, digital video, sound, 35:36

Courtesy the artist and Anna Schwartz Gallery
results.material_description: three channel video, projection, colour and audio
results.brief_description:
‘The Calling’ is a three-channel video installation that focuses on whistling languages, ancient forms of non-verbal communication which are still used in 2013 to communicate in isolated and difficult landscapes.

To conduct research for ‘The Calling’, artist Angelica Mesiti travelled to the village of Kuskoy in Northern Turkey, the island of La Gomera in The Canary Islands and the Island of Evia in Greece where whistling languages are all still in use.

For these communities, whistling languages are in a process of transformation from their traditional use as tools for communication across vast lands into tourist attractions and cultural artefacts and are being taught to local school children.

‘The Calling’ is a poignant exploration of ancient human traditions evolving and adapting to the modern world. The work speaks to the tenacity and creativity of traditional cultures in the face of globalisation, technological progress and environmental flux.

Angelica Mesiti was the winner of the inaugural Ian Potter Moving Image Commission.

results.title: Welcome to Cape Conran
results.creator_credit: Kim Montgomery, David Withers and ACMI
results.brief_description: Have you ever wondered what it’s like to live and work in a National Park? Cape Conran Coastal Park consists of 11,700 hectares of pristine coastal wilderness. Meet Carla and Josh Puglisi who manage the park as well as Mike Irvine; the park ranger, as they talk about the importance of protecting the coastal environment, the rich indigenous history of the area as well as what it’s like living within and raising families in such a beautiful place.

results.title: Paddle Steamer Curlip
results.creator_credit: Kim Montgomery, David Withers and ACMI
results.brief_description: Join a group of passionate volunteers as they describe the trials, tribulations and joys of building and running a paddle steamer. From the initial planning in 2002, a group of Orbost locals built the PS Curlip II as part of a community project. After 16,000 hours of voluntary labour the paddle steamer was launched and continues in 2013 to transport tourists in and around the various waterways of East Gippsland. Members of the PS Curlip Committee talk about the history, their involvement and the future of the much-loved paddle steamer.
